answers: ADHD [or Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder; do not accept “ADD” or “Attention Deficit Disorder”]
parts: Name this psychiatric disorder, which is often treated with Vyvanse or Adderall. A theory for its underdiagnosis in girls is that girls are more likely to have its inattentive type rather its hyperactive-impulsive type.
Vyvanse and Adderall belong to this class of drugs used to treat ADHD. These drugs generally increase metabolic activity.
Frequent comorbidities of ADHD are depression, anxiety, and this disruptive behavior disorder. It is characterized by anger and hostility towards figures of authority.
“Pi of x” is a function that returns the count of numbers under “x” that have this property, which means their only factors are one and itself.

Pi is also used to indicate this operation among the elements of a sequence. For a sequence of independent events, the probability that all events occur is this operation performed between the probability of each event.
Gauss used pi to symbolize a function where “pi of z equals gamma of z plus 1.” Because of the definition of the gamma function, Gauss’ pi function is essentially equal to this other function.
Name these places. The Internet Archive operates an “open” one of these places that has faced copyright violation accusations for mass scanning books and allowing unlimited borrowing.
“The Library of Babel” and “The Garden of Forking Paths” are included in Ficciones, a collection by this blind Argentinian author.
The experimental themes in Borges’ writing were a major influence on this literary movement of the 1960s and 70s. Its writers included Mario Vargas Llosa and Julio Cortazar.

answers: Piano Sonata No. 14 in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 2 [or Moonlight Sonata; accept BUT DO NOT REVEAL Beethoven’s Op. 27, No. 2]
pastoral or pastorale [accept Pastoral Sonata or Pastoral Symphony]
parts: Name this second of two piano sonatas published under the title Quasi una fantasia, which got its nickname when Ludwig Rellstab likened its first movement to a shimmering Lake Lucerne.
Moonlight Sonata is the fourteenth of thirty-two piano sonatas by this German composer of Für Elise, whose performing career was cut short due to deafness.

Directly after Moonlight Sonata in Beethoven’s opus catalog is the Piano Sonata No. 15, which the publisher gave this nickname. Beethoven would later use this name as the title of a programmatic symphony in F major.

answers: natural gas [prompt on gas; do not accept or prompt on “petroleum”]
parts: Many naturally occurring eternal flames are fueled by this non-oil hydrocarbon resource, which is sometimes “flared” off from oil wells and is primarily composed of methane. It is considered “cleaner” than oil or coal.

The Darvaza gas crater, which has been burning since geologists lit it in 1971, is located in this country’s portion of the Karakum Desert. This country’s southern border with Iran is formed by the Kopet Dag Mountains.

The Mrapen eternal flame, which has been burning since at least the 15th century, is considered sacred by the culture of this most populous island of Indonesia, which also contains its capital of Jakarta.

answers: St. Michael the Archangel [accept St. Michael the Taxiarch]
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints [accept the Mormon Church]
parts: Name this angel who is invoked in a prayer that asks him to “defend us in the hour of conflict.” The Book of Revelation relates how this archangel will lead God’s army to victory against Satan’s forces.

Members of this Christian denomination believe that the archangel Michael and Adam are one and the same. This religion’s founder discovered a set of gold plates which were revealed to him by the angel Moroni.
This other archangel helps Tobias marry the demon-tormented Sarah in the apocryphal Book of Tobit. The Babylonian Talmud relates that he appeared to Abraham along with Gabriel and Michael.

answers: figure skating [prompt on skating or ice skating]
parts: Name this sport, which features techniques like spirals, salchows, and lutzes performed on ice. Michelle Kwan was an American Olympian in this sport, which takes its name from the shapes competitors used to make.

This jump is the only figure skating jump with a forward takeoff, requiring an extra half rotation to complete. Mirai Nagasu became the first American woman to land the triple version of this jump at the 2018 Winter Olympics.

This Japanese figure skater became the first Asian skater to win men’s singles gold in 2014, and has broken 19 world records for points. His fans often throw Winnie the Pooh plushes onto the ice after his performances.

answers: Death [accept “Because I could not stop for Death –”]
the soul [accept “The Soul selects her own Society”]
parts: Name this literary character who “kindly stopped” for the narrator of a poem. In that poem, the narrator and this character ride in a carriage that held but “just Ourselves – / And Immortality.”
This “Belle of Amherst” wrote a poem beginning with the line, “Because I could not stop for Death –.”
In a poem by Emily Dickinson, this entity “selects her own Society.” In another poem, the speaker claims hope, which is “the thing with feathers,” “perches in” this entity.

answers: law codes [accept reasonable equivalents, such as legal systems; prompt on laws or codes]
parts: After founding the Mongol Empire, Genghis Khan created one of these systems, known as the Yassa, in order to maintain order. One of these systems created by Hammurabi of Babylon was carved into a stone stele.

Hulagu Khan was deeply interested in this scientific field and hired the Persian polymath Tusi to build the Maragheh observatory. Tusi’s observations in this field may have influenced Nicolas Copernicus’s heliocentrism.
This successor of Genghis Khan developed the Yam route system, a postal system so effective that Tsarist Russia kept it after the fall of the Golden Horde.
Name these hypothetical particles. Experiments like LIGO (“lye-go”) detect waves that may provide information about these particles.
While gravitons would be the quanta of the gravitational force, these particles are the quanta of the electromagnetic force. These massless particles are constantly travelling at the speed of light.
Because gravitons and photons both have integer spin, they are this type of particle. These particles can become superfluids when cooled and are contrasted with fermions.

Name this king of Phrygia (“FRIDGE-ee-uh”) who served his son Pelops to the Olympians, and was punished by being imprisoned in Tartarus in a pool of water and next to fruit branches that would recede whenever he reached for them.
This miserable fellow was bound to a constantly spinning fiery wheel in Tartarus for being the first human to kill his kin and, perhaps more seriously, for attempting to seduce Hera.
While the Greek gods sent mortals they wished to punish to Tartarus, this underworld, named after its patron god, was where the dead went in Greek mythology.

answers: Red Cross [accept International Red Cross or American Red Cross]
parts: Name this medical humanitarian organization whose American chapter was founded by Clara Barton.

The first battle monitored by the Red Cross was the Battle of Dybbøl (“DUE-bull”), which was lost by this country’s army. Later in the same war, this country led by Christian IX lost the duchies of Schleswig and Holstein to Prussia.

During World War II, this nation’s Red Cross assisted in the “White Buses” operation to rescue German prisoners. A diplomat from this country, Raoul Wallenberg, saved thousands of Jews during the Holocaust.

Name this rover that landed at Octavia Butler Landing Site in Jezero Crater on February 18th, 2021. Like its 2012 predecessor Curiosity, this vehicle used a hovering “sky crane” technique to soften the landing.
Jezero Crater was chosen as a landing site due to its proximity to an ancient river delta that might have traces of microbial life on this planet, the fourth planet from the Sun.

Under a directive from the Trump administration, NASA plans to also send more humans to the Moon.This program announced in 2019 with a mythological name seeks to put the first woman on the moon by 2024.

answers: deserting [accept abandoning his regiment or leaving his regiment]
parts: Name this story about four men stranded in a small dinghy. At the end of the story, the cook, captain, and correspondent swim to shore and find the oiler Billie dead on the beach.
This author of “The Open Boat” wrote about Henry Fleming in the novel The Red Badge of Courage.

Henry Fleming encounters the “tattered soldier” after taking this action at the beginning of the novel. He is hit on the head by a rifle after taking this action, but it is assumed he was grazed by a bullet in combat.
Name this 1642 painting that depicts Captain Franz Banning Cocq (“COKE”) and his militia company.
This Old Master of the Dutch Golden Age painted The Night Watch and depicted a dissection in The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp.
The Night Watch is on permanent loan to this museum, the most-visited in Amsterdam. In addition to the art collection, this museum also has a Michelin-starred restaurant inside.
Name this Ancient Greek historian, born in Halicarnassus. Despite their questionable historical accuracy, this man’s Histories have established his reputation as the “Father of History.”

Though Herodotus claimed to have visited Babylon, he does not include any mention of this place. The historian Stephanie Dalley has claimed this wonder was not in Babylon, but was built by Sennacherib in Nineveh.

This Roman scholar was the first to use the title “Father of History” for Herodotus. This man’s philosophy book De Oficiis was very influential in medieval Europe and was the third book printed by Johannes Gutenberg.
Name this steroid hormone, whose transport is facilitated by apolipoprotein (“aa-poh-lih-poh-protein”) B100. Buildup of this molecule on artery walls can lead to atherosclerosis.
Cholesterol is embedded into this structure to maintain fluidity at different temperatures. This structure is described by the fluid mosaic model and is composed of a phospholipid bilayer.

The risk of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease can be lowered by taking this class of drugs, which inhibit HMG-CoA reductase. This class of drugs is the most commonly prescribed to lower cholesterol levels.

answers: Disney [accept Walt Disney Concert Hall; accept Disney World]
parts: Name this country, in which iconic buildings like the Moshe Safdie-designed Habitat 67 and Buckminster Fuller’s Biosphere were constructed for the 1967 World Expo.
This Canadian-born architect designed the Art Gallery of Ontario, as well as the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao and the Stata Center at MIT.
Gehry also designed a Los Angeles concert hall named for the founder of this company. This company’s EPCOT theme park contains Spaceship Earth, a geodesic dome inspired by Buckminster Fuller.
Name this concept. Epistemology is the study of this concept, which Immanuel Kant divided into a priori and a posteriori types in his Critique of Pure Reason.
This theory claims that we gain knowledge only from sense experience, in contrast with rationalism. W.V.O. Quine wrote “Two Dogmas of [this theory].”
In An Essay Concerning Human Understanding, John Locke uses this term to describe the human mind before any sense experience.

Name this folk song whose techno version by the band Rednex was featured on their album Sex & Violins. If it weren’t for the title character of this song, the singer would “been married long time ago.”

Despite their attire, Rednex is from this European country that hosts the annual Way Out West festival. The YouTube series iamamiwhoami (“i-am-am-i-who-am-i”) by singer Jonna Lee was produced in this country.

This Swedish EDM artist of “Lover” created the dance mix of a song that says to do the title action “when I’m wiser and I’m older.” This artist’s album Tim was released posthumously after his death in Oman.

answers: Don Juan (“don JOO-in” in Byron’s pronunciation)
Hell [accept “Don Juan in Hell” or “hell is other people”]
parts: Name this fictional libertine who first appeared in The Trickster of Seville by Tirso de Molina. Lord Byron’s verse satire imposes an English pronunciation on this man’s Spanish name.

This playwright wrote Man and Superman at the urging of the critic Arthur Walkley, who had told him to write a Don Juan play. This man’s own criticism includes the essay “The Quintessence of Ibsenism.”
Act III of Shaw’s Man and Superman depicts Don Juan in this place. In Jean-Paul Sartre’s No Exit, the journalist Garcin concludes that this place “is other people.”
Name this concept that considers how different identities, such as race, gender, and sexuality, interact with each other.
The third wave of this movement for gender liberation began in the 1990s, and emphasizes topics like intersectionality and sex positivity.
This feminist thinker and activist wrote about intersectionality in Ain’t I A Woman and discussed educating students to be free in Teaching to Transgress.

answers: concrete [prompt on cement with “what is the cement used for?”]
parts: Name this alkaline composite material. One reaction in this material referred to as its namesake “cancer” causes the formation of water-absorbing gel that induces swelling.
Concrete cancer is caused by a reaction between alkaline cement and this compound, the major constituent in sand. The vast majority of this compound’s commercial use is in concrete.

Another compound that degrades concrete is this substance that deposits onto concrete as white efflorescence. Sodium chloride, a type of this substance, can corrode rebar and may be introduced via de-icing or seawater.

answers: “Give me liberty or give me death!”
American Revolutionary War [or Revolutionary War or American War of Independence]
parts: Name this phrase delivered during a speech to the Second Virginia Convention. This phrase embodied colonial disgust against taxation by the British Parliament.

“Give me liberty or give me death” did not enter the popular consciousness until this man’s biography of Patrick Henry. He would later serve as Attorney General for 12 years, the longest tenure in American history.
Patrick Henry’s rhetoric was critical to charging up colonists in the run up to this conflict which began with the Battles of Lexington and Concord in April 1775.
